image.altText: Senator Patrick Dodson sits in front of an Aboriginal flag, wearing a wide brim hat with a red, yellow and black stripped band.

items.synopsis: Follow our live coverage of the Voice to Parliament campaign on Wednesday, October 11.

title.children: Pat Dodson says Voice will give Indigenous Australians 'responsibility' for their futures

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Senator Dodson was asked to explain how the Voice will fix injustices against Indigenous people. "You need to establish you were here prior to the establishment of the colonisation. What we're seeing the referendum to recognise the first peoples of these lands. The second thing we're saying is they ought to have a say to the Parliament and the executive on matters their communities have concerns about how the Parliament remains in place. There's nothing scary about that. There's absolutely nothing scary about it. There's nothing to be fearful about it. If you are confused, look in mirror and say is a good thing to do that?"
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dodson's message to the undecided "If you are confused, look in mirror"

children.content: Senator Dodson was asked to explain how the Voice will fix injustices against Indigenous people.
"You need to establish you were here prior to the establishment of the colonisation.

What we're seeing the referendum to recognise the first peoples of these lands. The second thing we're saying is they ought to have a say to the Parliament and the executive on matters their communities have concerns about how the Parliament remains in place.
There's nothing scary about that.
There's absolutely nothing scary about it.
There's nothing to be fearful about it.
If you are confused, look in mirror and say is a good thing to do that?"

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Senator Dodson said he was worried about the future of funding and support for Aboriginal nations if the No vote succeeds in the referendum. "We have this opportunity now with the referendum to change the way we relate to one another and the way governments go about their business. "If you want the government to deliver more of the same or to become more draconian, then vote No. "If you don't want them to go down that path, vote Yes."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: No vote win will lead to 'more draconian' government, says Dodson

children.content: Senator Dodson said he was worried about the future of funding and support for Aboriginal nations if the No vote succeeds in the referendum.
"We have this opportunity now with the referendum to change the way we relate to one another and the way governments go about their business.
"If you want the government to deliver more of the same or to become more draconian, then vote No.
"If you don't want them to go down that path, vote Yes."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's what Senator Dodson had to say when asked what he thinks of polls predicting a No vote win. "Polls tell you lies and don't believe them." "I don't believe in the polls. I was in the opposition when Bill Shorten was the leader and we thought we would win government and of course we got the biggest hiding possible and never went anywhere. Polls tell you lies and don't believe them. If you are fearful about the confusion, vote Yes. Don't vote No because No takes you nowhere."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'I don't believe in the polls'

children.content: Here's what Senator Dodson had to say when asked what he thinks of polls predicting a No vote win.
"Polls tell you lies and don't believe them."

"I don't believe in the polls. I was in the opposition when Bill Shorten was the leader and we thought we would win government and of course we got the biggest hiding possible and never went anywhere. Polls tell you lies and don't believe them. If you are fearful about the confusion, vote Yes. Don't vote No because No takes you nowhere."

title.children: Australian grandmother Galit Carbone confirmed killed in Israel

image.altText: Women weep as they embrace each other in a Gaza street

items.synopsis: Israeli media reports the death toll from the Hamas attacks has reached 1,200, as a Palestinian UN envoy says Israel's bombardment of the Gaza Strip is "nothing less than genocidal".

title.children: Israel death toll reportedly reaches 1,200, Palestinian envoy accuses Israel of 'genocidal' campaign in Gaza

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A Palestinian doctor has painted a grim picture of life in Gaza under Israeli bombardment. Khamis Elessi, who is a neuro-rehabilitation and pain medicine consultant at the Islamic University of Gaza, told ABC News Radio he felt as if he was in a scene from the Living Dead. "As I'm talking to you there are 13 people who've been brought from under the rubble of their homes without any prior warning, so the house was demolished on top of the residents," he said. Other times people were left running blindly looking for shelter after being given just minutes to evacuate. "The next morning you open your windows and you look through it and you find it's still dark — even though it's 7am or 8am — not because there is no sun but because everything is covered with a thick layer of smog and smoke and fires are still igniting in so many buildings and so many roads,” he said. “People running amongst the shrapnel, the debris … car windows broken and they are running to seek new shelter and they are crying and their faces are covered with dark black smoke, they look like they are coming from Return of the Living Dead. It's just like an action movie about zombies." Doctors used to treating people in pain are now struggling to treat shrapnel wounds, and devasting injuries from explosions. "The vast majority of injuries are children, the vast majority of dead are children and next to them is women unfortunately," he said, adding that without sufficient medicine or equipment doctors could not save them. He said hospitals were overwhelmed and not equipped to receive "2,000 patients a day" with morgues full and ice-cream refrigerators being used to store the dead.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Palestinian doctor says he feels like he is in a scene from the Living Dead

children.content: A
Palestinian
doctor has painted a grim picture of life in Gaza under Israeli bombardment.
Khamis Elessi
, who is a neuro-rehabilitation and pain medicine consultant at the Islamic University of Gaza, told ABC News Radio he felt as if he was in a scene from the Living Dead.
"As I'm talking to you there are 13 people who've been brought from under the rubble of their homes without any prior warning, so the house was demolished on top of the residents," he said.
Other times people were left running blindly looking for shelter after being given just minutes to evacuate.

"The next morning you open your windows and you look through it and you find it's still dark — even though it's 7am or 8am — not because there is no sun but because everything is covered with a thick layer of smog and smoke and fires are still igniting in so many buildings and so many roads,” he said.

“People running amongst the shrapnel, the debris … car windows broken and they are running to seek new shelter and they are crying and their faces are covered with dark black smoke, they look like they are coming from Return of the Living Dead. It's just like an action movie about zombies."
Palestinian doctor Khamis Elessi.
(Supplied)
Doctors used to treating people in pain are now struggling to treat shrapnel wounds, and devasting injuries from explosions.

"The vast majority of injuries are children, the vast majority of dead are children and next to them is women unfortunately," he said, adding that without sufficient medicine or equipment doctors could not save them.
He said hospitals were overwhelmed and not equipped to receive "2,000 patients a day" with morgues full and ice-cream refrigerators being used to store the dead.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: An Israeli citizen and Australian resident has spoken of his fears for cousins who remain missing after the weekend's devasting terror attack by Hamas. Darwin man Tai Bahar said he and other family members had no way of knowing what happened to his cousins who were at the Supernova music festival. "That is the hard thing but with all this happening right now, there is so much uncertainty, with everything going on and they have been missing for over three days," he told ABC News Channel. "There is no way to know what they have been through, what is going on and where they are." Mr Bahar also spoke of his relief that friends in Kfa Azza kibbutz, 5km outside Gaza, who had to hide in their safe room with their children when terrorists came and started shooting, are now safe. " My friend, her husband and her two kids - one is three years old and the other one is a year old and they had to hide in the safe room as the terrorists arrived into the Kibbutz, her husband held the door because the secure room is designed for bomb attacks, not for anyone trying to infiltrate," he said. "They had to manually hold the door to keep it safe and he held that for 27 hours as they tried to shoot at the door, trying to put all the furniture and burn them so they could go and kill them or whatever," "They hid there for 27 hours. You can imagine having a 3-year-old and young baby, that is unimaginable."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israeli in Australia says friends had to hide for 27 hours when terrorists started shooting

mediaThumbnail.caption: Tai Bahar is an Israeli citizen with residency in Australia, who has family and friends affected by the attacks.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: NSW police has announced an operation to co-ordinate the reponse to demonstrations and events relating to the Hamas attack. NSW Acting Commissioner David Hudson says Operation Shelter will capture all intelligence available on community sentiment, potential protest activity and potential demonstrations. "This is not ideal that we have to take the steps to co-ordinate our activity across the state," he said. "There has been a fair bit of activity over the past few days which we believe will continue into the foreseeable future. "I think it is incumbent upon us to stand up to this standalone operation to co-ordinate activities not just within the city region but also across the broader state of New South Wales." Acting Commissioner Hudson says the intent of the operation is to "ensure community safety". "We will take any steps to ensure that," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NSW police announces Operation Shelter to 'ensure community safety'

NSW Acting Commissioner David Hudson says Operation Shelter will capture all intelligence available on community sentiment, potential protest activity and potential demonstrations.
"This is not ideal that we have to take the steps to co-ordinate our activity across the state," he said.
"There has been a fair bit of activity over the past few days which we believe will continue into the foreseeable future.
"I think it is incumbent upon us to stand up to this standalone operation to co-ordinate activities not just within the city region but also across the broader state of New South Wales."
Acting Commissioner Hudson says the intent of the operation is to "ensure community safety".
"We will take any steps to ensure that," he said.

items.synopsis: Qantas chairman Richard Goyder has continued to defy public pressure to immediately step down, by announcing he will retire next year, while the Australian share market has risen for its fifth day in a row as concerns about higher-for-longer interest rates subsided. Follow live.

title.children: Qantas board set for a shakeup as Richard Goyder becomes the latest high-profile exit, ASX rises for fifth straight day

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Bank of Queensland shares have plunged by more than 5% today, after the lender revealed its annual profit plunged by about 70% amid depressed mortgage lending, and flagged margin pressure. BoQ posted a statutory net profit after tax of $124 million for the year ended August 31 (compared with $409 million a year earlier). The bank cut its final dividend to 21 cents per share (down from last year's 24 cents apiece). Net interest margin fell to 1.69% (compared with a restated 2022 number of 1.71%). This is the difference between the rate at which the bank borrows money and lends it to customers. The bank recorded a one-off impairment charge of more than $300 million, which also hit its earnings. BoQ expects revenue and margin pressures to continue into the current financial year, reflecting credit growth and competition, while flagging a possible low single-digit cost growth. "A very weak result, with the likelihood of further negative revisions to FY24 consensus expectations," analysts at Citi said in a note, adding that the management would have a "tough task in building credibility in their medium-term productivity story." "We recognise that this has been a difficult year for our shareholders and take accountability for the operational risk failings," BOQ CEO Patrick Allaway said in a statement. By 12:40pm AEDT, Bank of Queensland's share price was down 5.3% to $5.47.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bank of Queensland annual profit plunges 70 per cent

children.content: Bank of Queensland shares have plunged by more than 5% today, after the lender revealed its annual profit plunged by about 70% amid depressed mortgage lending, and flagged margin pressure.
BoQ posted a statutory net profit after tax of $124 million for the year ended August 31 (compared with $409 million a year earlier).
The bank cut its final dividend to 21 cents per share (down from last year's 24 cents apiece).
Net interest margin fell to 1.69% (compared with a restated 2022 number of 1.71%). This is the difference between the rate at which the bank borrows money and lends it to customers.
The bank recorded a one-off impairment charge of more than $300 million, which also hit its earnings.
BoQ expects revenue and margin pressures to continue into the current financial year, reflecting credit growth and competition, while flagging a possible low single-digit cost growth.

"A very weak result, with the likelihood of further negative revisions to FY24 consensus expectations," analysts at Citi said in a note, adding that the management would have a "tough task in building credibility in their medium-term productivity story."
"We recognise that this has been a difficult year for our shareholders and take accountability for the operational risk failings," BOQ CEO Patrick Allaway said in a statement.
By 12:40pm AEDT, Bank of Queensland's share price was down 5.3% to $5.47.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas has been a mainstay in the headlines for months now, and pressure has been slowly but steadily mounting on the airline's board — and specifically Richard Goyder — to step down after one of the most tumultuous periods in its history. There's been the flight credits saga, delayed and cancelled flights, customer service complaints, a class action, and an ACCC investigation over allegations it sold tickets for cancelled flights. But that was only the beginning — on top of Alan Joyce's early exit, the High Court's ruling that Qantas illegally sacked 1,700 ground crew, and the multi-million-dollar payout for Joyce and its executives disclosed in its annual report. And it was just two weeks ago today that Richard Goyder, along with CEO Vanessa Hudson and Qantas' general counsel Andrew Finch, appeared at a Senate inquiry into the federal government's blocking of additional Qatar Airways flights. It was in that fiery hearing that Richard Goyder said not once, but twice, that he had the support of Qantas shareholders ( despite shareholders withdrawing their support for him a day earlier, and putting the rest of the board on notice ). As the popular saying goes, timing is everything — so why has Richard Goyder made the announcement now, when his exit isn't until sometime next year? The ABC's senior business correspondent Peter Ryan has unpacked what the timing means, how it will impact next month's annual general meeting in Melbourne, and how Qantas might move forward. You can watch his full assessment of the situation below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 📺 What's behind the timing of Qantas chair Richard Goyder's exit announcement?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Transport Workers' Union has wasted no time in criticising Richard Goyder's retirement plans announced this morning, saying he's attempting "to retire in dignity after presiding over illegal conduct". The TWU's statement references the High Court's unanimous ruling that Qantas acted illegally when it sacked about 1,700 ground crew and replaced them with contractors during the COVID-19 pandemic. The union says Mr Goyder should follow former CEO Alan Joyce in an early exit from the airline this year. TWU national secretary Michael Kaine believes Mr Goyder should depart sooner rather than later so he doesn't escape accountability, and allow for a total governance reset at the airline. "This announcement is an attempt by Goyder to leave in a dignified manner with another year's pay in his pocket, after presiding over the largest case of illegal sackings in Australian history," Mr Kaine said. "This isn't genuine board renewal, this is just shuffling the deckchairs. We need to put an end to illegal conduct being blindly rubber-stamped by a board that fails to scrutinise the CEO who is treated as their equal by having a place on the board. "With no worker representation, Qantas governance has ignored the needs of the workforce and decimated jobs and standards. " A fresh start for Qantas governance requires a new board composition that excludes the CEO and embeds a worker representative to avoid the repeat of colossal errors of judgement being repeated."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Goyder's exit from Qantas is 'just shuffling the deckchairs', Transport Workers' Union says

"This announcement is

this is just shuffling the deckchairs
. We need to put an end to illegal conduct being blindly rubber-stamped by a board that fails to scrutinise the CEO who is treated as their equal by having a place on the board.
"With no worker representation,
Qantas governance has ignored the needs of the workforce
and decimated jobs and standards.
A fresh start for Qantas governance requires a new board composition that excludes the CEO
and embeds a worker representative
to avoid the repeat of colossal errors of judgement being repeated."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: SEN, AFL.com.au and The Age are reporting the deal has been struck, with the clubs and league soon to confirm it. Sydney have traded Dylan Stephens and pick 25 to North Melbourne for pick 44 and a future end-of-first-round pick. Interesting to see that pick 25 on the move. The Grundy/Adams picture shifts yet again. I would imagine that selection will soon be sent to Carlton to get Zac Fisher to North as well. UPDATE : The AFL has now confirmed the deal.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dylan Stephens has been traded to North Melbourne

children.content: (Getty Images)
SEN, AFL.com.au and The Age are reporting the deal has been struck, with the clubs and league soon to confirm it.
Sydney have traded Dylan Stephens and pick 25 to North Melbourne for pick 44 and a future end-of-first-round pick.
Interesting to see that pick 25 on the move. The Grundy/Adams picture shifts yet again.
I would imagine that selection will soon be sent to Carlton to get Zac Fisher to North as well.
UPDATE
: The AFL has now confirmed the deal.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The latest in our look at the 2023 draft class is an exciting player with a familiar name, who has rocketed up into top three calculations in recent months. Zane Duursma is a hybrid forward, tall and strong in the air and on the lead but just as deadly when the ball hits the deck. Duursma is an intelligent and skilful player who can also work his defenders over with his impressive tank. Duursma kicked a mountain of goals this year for both Vic Country and the Gippsland Power, and by the end of the season was probably the hottest player in the Coates League. He can float in and out of games, but can be absolutely devastating with only a handful of touches. He's also flagged an interest in moving into the midfield later in his career, but for the first few years at least Duursma will be a dangerous half-forward, a tough match-up for the opposition due to his wide range of abilities. The top five in this year's draft looms large for clubs on the look out for a touch of class.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Draft Spotlight — Zane Duursma

Duursma kicked a mountain of goals this year for both Vic Country and the Gippsland Power, and by the end of the season was probably the hottest player in the Coates League. He can float in and out of games, but can be absolutely devastating with only a handful of touches.

He's also flagged an interest in moving into the midfield later in his career, but for the first few years at least Duursma will be a dangerous half-forward, a tough match-up for the opposition due to his wide range of abilities.
The top five in this year's draft looms large for clubs on the look out for a touch of class.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: While it's probably a bit of a feeler, do you think that Collingwood's purported offer of pick 19 for Lachie Schultz, considering the comments from Peter Bell, is a bit disingenuous for both Schults and Fremantle, or do you think it's a fair offer? - MikeP. I don't think it's miles away, but it's not going to be enough. If I know Peter Bell and Fremantle, they will be waiting to see what Collingwood get back for Taylor Adams and will then be asking for both that and pick 19. That is probably too far the other way, but if a deal is to be done it will probably end up somewhere in the middle of that. There have also been reports that Freo are trying to stack up 2024 picks for a crack at some big-name recruits — Logan McDonald is the one most commonly mentioned — so perhaps that is something they might ask for from Collingwood. For all of Bell's comments that Freo are prepared to hold Schultz to his contract, I'm quite sure a deal will be done at some point between now and next Wednesday night.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How close are Collingwood to Lachie Schultz?

children.content: While it's probably a bit of a feeler, do you think that Collingwood's purported offer of pick 19 for Lachie Schultz, considering the comments from Peter Bell, is a bit disingenuous for both Schults and Fremantle, or do you think it's a fair offer?
- MikeP
I don't think it's miles away, but it's not going to be enough.
(Getty Images)

If I know Peter Bell and Fremantle, they will be waiting to see what Collingwood get back for Taylor Adams and will then be asking for both that and pick 19. That is probably too far the other way, but if a deal is to be done it will probably end up somewhere in the middle of that.

There have also been reports that Freo are trying to stack up 2024 picks for a crack at some big-name recruits — Logan McDonald is the one most commonly mentioned — so perhaps that is something they might ask for from Collingwood.
For all of Bell's comments that Freo are prepared to hold Schultz to his contract, I'm quite sure a deal will be done at some point between now and next Wednesday night.

image.altText: a outback shelter with cars and charging and solar panels

items.synopsis: There are not many electric car chargers along one of Australia's longest roads, but one local company has developed a prototype it hopes will help range anxiety in the outback.

title.children: 'It's very novel': Could this portable charger with solar panels solve range anxiety in the outback?

image.altText: Flames in the background engulf a multistorey car park, in the foreground is a sign to the car park

items.synopsis: Luton Airport says it has suspended all flights, and part of its car park has partially collapsed.

title.children: Flights suspended after fire breaks out, causes car park collapse at Luton Airport near London

image.altText: The ruins of houses and buildings sit among the grey rubble of other destroyed buildings.

items.synopsis: As attacks from both sides escalate and the death toll rises, there are fears people will be trapped in Gaza with no humanitarian corridor after further air strikes leave neighbourhoods reduced to rubble.

title.children: Israel destroys whole Gaza neighbourhoods as defence minister tells his forces offensive will 'intensify'

image.altText: Israeli soldiers carry the body of a victim of an attack by militants from Gaza .

items.synopsis: Israeli soldiers begin the grim work of collecting the bodies of those killed in Hamas' terror attack as rockets continue to fly overhead.

title.children: Killed 'in their beds and protection rooms': Inside Kfar Aza kibbutz after Hamas terrorists attacked

image.altText: Caroline Ellison walks through the door of the Federal Court in New York City with a backpack on one shoulder

items.synopsis: Caroline Ellison, the tech executive who ran Bankman-Fried’s hedge fund while sometimes dating him, tells the court he directed her to commit fraud.

title.children: Key moment in Sam Bankman-Fried's fraud case as ex-girlfriend testifies against former crypto billionaire

image.altText: Chinese flags near the logo Evergrande Centre in Shanghai, China, on September 24, 2021.

items.synopsis: Australia's biggest trading partner is facing its biggest economic slowdown in decades, and the Reserve Bank has warned that stress in China's economy will be felt across the world — including here in Australia.

title.children: How a 'sharp deterioration' in China's property market could affect housing affordability in Australia

image.altText: Chris Minns stands at a school yard

items.synopsis: A protest organiser with the Palestinian Action Group Sydney said they would launch a legal challenge after Chris Minns moved to shut down a march through the city this Sunday.

title.children: Minns says planned pro-Palestinian rally will not be allowed to 'commandeer Sydney streets'

image.altText: Holly Willoughby in a dress standing on a red carpet and smiling as fans stand behind a barrier behind her

items.synopsis: Holly Willoughby announces she is stepping down from her presenting role on daytime programme This Morning, days after a man was charged in connection with an alleged plot to kidnap and murder her.

title.children: Holly Willoughby quits UK daytime show This Morning amid kidnap and murder allegations

image.altText: A woman sits on a park bench and looks at her phone.

items.synopsis: The telecommunications watchdog releases its annual report card on the country's telcos, and while complaints are down across the board, there’s one notable exception — Optus.

title.children: 'I don't have time to be fixing up big companies' errors': Industry report shows rise of complaints about Optus

image.altText: Penelope Towney 3

items.synopsis: First inspired by the Black Lives Matter movement, the young First Nations trailblazer wants to preserve her culture and language for generations to come.

title.children: Penelope made her first film when she was seven, now she's sharing her Indigenous culture on YouTube

image.altText: Justin Choveaux stands with another firefighter next to a vegetation fire at night.

items.synopsis: A key group representing Queensland's volunteer fire brigades pours water on the idea of a "semi-professional firefighting service" akin to the Army Reserve, saying it could alienate those already tackling this year's bushfire season.

title.children: Rural brigades boss hoses down talk of national firefighting force

image.altText: A young woman wearing sunglasses looks out a car window

items.synopsis: Tasmania's public housing overcrowding rates are higher than the national average and continue to grow, with one family in Hobart's northern suburbs given priority status still waiting after four years.

title.children: Katlyn's been told she can't get a bigger house for her growing family, so she drives around looking for one

image.altText: A medium shot of a man supported by a cable while dangling from a platform under a bridge, over water with a man on the platform

items.synopsis: Mike Heard completed 500 more jumps than his previous record, and credits much of his success to working on his mental health.

title.children: New Zealand man bungee jumps 941 times in one day to reclaim world record

image.altText: A woman and a young man stand next to each other arm in arm

items.synopsis: Russell Martin, who lives with dementia, jokes that he's learned a trick or two from Mother and Son's eccentric matriarch Maggie, but does the show reflect the reality of living with the condition?

title.children: The original Mother and Son never mentioned dementia. Why not then, and why now?

image.altText: A young woman with dark skin and black hair wearing yellow headphones looks at a yellow smartphone

items.synopsis: While some are optimistic about the streaming giant's move into audiobooks, others fear it will threaten authors' already precarious livelihoods.

title.children: Authors fear Spotify's move into audiobooks risks 'killing the golden goose'

image.altText: A soldier in military uniform and holding a gun stands in front of a destroyed apartment building with emergency crews.

items.synopsis: To prepare their soldiers for the psychological challenges of combat, the Ukrainian military has developed a sophisticated resilience training program. Its insights may be very valuable to other militaries — including the ADF, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Ukraine's military has invested heavily in resilience training. The ADF should take note

image.altText: Silhouette of a man standing on a shoreline at sunset looking out at an oil rig on the ocean.

items.synopsis: It could take hundreds of years — if not thousands — to reverse decline to ocean fish habitat if warming's not kept below climate targets, according to new research.

title.children: A 'double whammy' for fish — and humans — if climate targets are overshot

image.altText: A man looks at the camera.

items.synopsis: Aboriginal people are considering what the Voice might mean for them, and if they want it at all. The ABC visited several regional communities in Queensland and listened. Here's what they had to say.

title.children: Fred has 'lost a lot of white friends' in the lead up to the referendum. He hopes they can reconcile their differences
